measured_by: Percentage of risky choices in the Marble Task
justification: “After participants completed a block without social information (solo condition), we computed the percentage of trials at which the current subject chose the risky option,” indicating that the proportion of risky choices serves as the empirical index of risk preference.

measured_by: Social-influence parameter η estimated by the hierarchical Bayesian model
justification: “η was almost exclusively greater than 1 … the posterior mean estimates of η constitute the weight of social information on our subjects' decisions,” showing that the model parameter η quantifies each participant’s sensitivity to social influence.

measured_by: Variance of the Beta distribution over expected utility
justification: The authors state, “We denote the variance of the Beta distribution as uncertainty,” explicitly defining the Beta-variance as their measure of a participant’s subjective uncertainty regarding option utilities.

measured_by: Slider rating of the underlying probability in the Marble Task
justification: “Before making a choice, we asked participants to indicate their estimate of the underlying probability, using a slider,” demonstrating that slider responses operationalize participants’ perceived probabilities.

measured_by: Weighted-updating parameter κ in the Bayesian model
justification: The Methods section notes that the parameter κ “allows us to express ‘weighted updating’ where estimates close to one indicate Bayesian optimality; values lower than one mean that subjects underweight new information,” establishing κ as the quantitative measure of how strongly individuals weight incoming evidence.
